comment.author: 47615881@N00
comment._content: Just doesn't look like Mississippi to me. Maybe Florida?  I'm looking at the grass and the trees and also the clothing.  If it is Mississippi, it is probably southern Mississippi.  I'm from Mississippi by the way.

comment.author: 23256190@N08
comment._content: The trees appear to be Norfolk / Australian pines, which are common (but non-native) to south Florida.

comment.author: 45499740@N00
comment._content: Looks like South Mississippi, where some of my family is from.  Same kind of sandy ground and pines.

comment.author: 25036263@N02
comment._content: 1940 was < my time. I notice Ms. Marion Post Wolcott photographed in Natchez, Clarksdale, Louisiana, Florida, Georgia, Tennessee, and Kentucky so the government department might have it wrong. I was raised near Greenville and worked in the fields with the agricultural black folk. They dressed better in the 1960s than in WW2.. The trees are bending in the wind so I cannot ID them. They aren't red cedar or anything common here. If it was near the coast the gravel would be oyster shells (say if it was Stone or George County).

comment.author: 28826708@N03
comment._content: The truck is a 34-36 International flatbed.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: carphoto and fiat128: thanks for your identification of the truck.  We will update the information and reload the description.

comment.author: 76945118@N00
comment._content: They look like Australian pines to me

comment.author: 39098008@N08
comment._content: I cant believe how wonderful the quality of these images are.  If it weren't for the old model cars and trucks--I'd think they were taken today.  A bit eerie because I see the faces of people I feel I know.
